title: Quick Protocol for Extraction and Purification of Genomic DNA
title_html: Quick Protocol for Extraction and Purification of Genomic DNA

protocol.title: Quick Protocol for Extraction and Purification of Genomic DNA
protocol.title_html: Quick Protocol for Extraction and Purification of Genomic DNA

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Please select the sample material that you want to use:
  • Cultured Cells
  • Mammalian Whole Blood (non-nucleated)
  • Nucleated Whole Blood (birds, reptiles)
  • Animal Tissue

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Start with a cell pellet containing 1 x 104 – 5 x 106 cells (typical starting amount is 1 x 106 cells).
Frozen cells: thaw cell pellet slowly on ice and loosen by flicking the tube several times. Resuspend in
cold PBS by pipetting up and down.
Fresh cells: pellet by centrifugation at
for
and resuspend in
cold PBS by pipetting up and down.
Ensure pellet is resuspended completely. If using lower cell inputs, the use of carrier RNA may be beneficial; see 
product manual 
for details.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
Proteinase K and
RNase A to the resuspended pellet and mix by vortexing briefly to ensure the enzymes are efficiently dispersed.

source.body: Do not add the enzymes and the Cell Lysis Buffer simultaneously, as the high viscosity of the lysate will prevent equal distribution of the enzymes. Addition of RNase A can be omitted if a low percentage of co-purified RNA will not affect downstream applications.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
Cell Lysis Buffer and vortex immediately and thoroughly. The solution will rapidly become viscous.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Incubate for
at
in a thermal mixer with agitation at full speed (~
).

source.body: Incubation for longer than 5 minutes is not necessary, but will not negatively affect the quality of the purified gDNA. If a thermal mixer is not available, use a heating block and vortex occasionally.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Transfer
of whole blood to a 1.5 ml microfuge tube.
If processing less than 100 μl of blood, add cold PBS to bring the total volume to 100 μl.
For pre-aliquoted frozen samples, do not thaw; add Proteinase K, RNase A and Blood Lysis Buffer to the frozen sample in step 3.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
Proteinase K,
RNase A and
of Blood Lysis Buffer. Mix immediately by vortexing.

source.body: For frozen samples, do not thaw; add reagents and lysis buffer to frozen sample and immediately proceed to step 4. When working with multiple samples, prepare a master mix of the three reagents to save pipetting steps. Addition of RNase A can be omitted if a low percentage of co-purified RNA will not affect downstream applications.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Incubate for
at
in a thermal mixer with agitation at full speed (~
).

source.body: Incubation for longer than 5 minutes is not necessary, but will not negatively affect the quality of the purified gDNA from most species. If a thermal mixer is not available, use a heating block and vortex occasionally.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Transfer
whole blood to a 1.5 ml microfuge tube.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
cold PBS and mix by vortexing.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
Proteinase K and
RNase A, and mix again by vortexing.

source.body: Do not add the enzymes and the Blood Lysis Buffer simultaneously, as the high viscosity of the lysate will prevent equal distribution of the enzymes. Addition of RNase A can be omitted if a low percentage of co-purified RNA will not affect downstream applications.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
Blood Lysis Buffer and vortex thoroughly. The solution will rapidly become viscous.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Incubate for
at
in a thermal mixer with agitation at full speed (~
).

source.body: Incubation for longer than 5 minutes is not necessary, but will not negatively affect the quality of the purified gDNA.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description: Cut tissue into small pieces to ensure rapid lysis and high yields.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add Proteinase K (according to the table below) and
of Tissue Lysis Buffer to each sample. Mix immediately by vortexing.
AB
1TISSUE TYPEPROTEINASE K AMOUNT
2Brain, Kidney, Skin, Ear Clips3 μl
3All other tissues10 μl

source.body: Ensure tissue particles are able to move freely in the lysis mix and do not remain stuck on the bottom of the tube. When working with multiple samples, prepare a master mix of Tissue Lysis Buffer and Proteinase K to save pipetting steps.

source.description:
AB
1TISSUE TYPEPROTEINASE K AMOUNT
2Brain, Kidney, Skin, Ear Clips3 μl
3All other tissues10 μl

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Incubate at
in a thermal mixer with agitation at full speed (
) until tissue pieces have completely dissolved (typically
–
).

source.body: If time is not limiting, additional incubation up to 3 hours can further improve yields and decrease residual RNA. If an incubator with agitation is not available, use a tube rotator placed within an incubator, shaking water bath or a heating block (vortex samples every 5-15 minutes to speed up lysis).

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Note: The following step can be omitted when working with fresh or frozen tissue amounts <15 mg.
Centrifuge for maximum speed
to pellet debris. Transfer the supernatant to a fresh microfuge tube.

source.body: This prevents residual debris from clogging the membrane binding sites and helps to reach maximal yield and purity. It is especially important to perform this step if sample appears turbid, contains residual particles, when working with stabilized tissue, or when working with brain or fibrous tissues.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Add
of RNase A to the lysate, vortex thoroughly, and incubate for a minimum of
at
with agitation at full speed.

source.body: This step can be skipped if a low percentage of co-purified RNA will not affect downstream applications.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description: Proceed to step 1 of Part 2: Genomic DNA Binding and Elution

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Add
gDNA Binding Buffer to the sample and mix thoroughly by pulse-vortexing for
–
.

source.body: Thorough mixing is essential for optimal results.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Transfer the lysate/binding buffer mix (~
) to a gDNA Purification Column pre-inserted into a collection tube, without touching the upper column area. Proceed immediately to step 8.

source.body: Avoid touching the upper column area with lysate/binding mix and avoid transferring foam that may have formed during lysis. Any material that touches the upper area of the column, including any foam, may lead to salt contamination in the eluate.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Close the cap and centrifuge: first for
at
to bind gDNA (no need to empty the collection tubes or remove from centrifuge) and then for
at maximum speed (>
) to clear the membrane. Discard the flow-through and the collection tube.

source.body: For optimal results, ensure that the spin column is placed in the centrifuge in the same orientation at each spin step (for example, always with the hinge pointing to the outside of the centrifuge); ensuring the liquid follows the same path through the membrane for binding and elution can slightly improve yield and consistency.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Transfer column to a new collection tube and add
gDNA Wash Buffer.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Reinsert the column into the collection tube. Add
gDNA Wash Buffer and close the cap. Centrifuge immediately for
at maximum speed (>
), then discard the collection tube and flow through.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description: Place the gDNA Purification Column in a DNase-free 1.5 ml microfuge tube (not included).

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Centrifuge for
at maximum speed (>
) to elute the gDNA.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Close the cap and invert a few times, so that the wash buffer reaches the cap. Centrifuge immediately for
at maximum speed (
), and discard the flow through. The collection tube can be tapped on a paper towel to remove any residual buffer before reusing it in the next step.

source.body: Inverting the spin column containing wash buffer prevents salt contamination in the eluate.

source.title: PART 2: GENOMIC DNA BINDING AND ELUTION

source.description:
Add
–
preheated (
) gDNA Elution Buffer, close the cap and incubate at
for
.

source.body: Elution in 100 μl is recommended, but smaller volumes can be used and will result in more concentrated DNA but a reduced yield (20 – 25 % reduction when using 35 μl). Eluting with preheated elution buffer will increase yields by ~ 20 – 40 % and eliminates the need for a second elution. For applications in which a high DNA concentration is required, using a small elution volume and then eluting again with the eluate may increase yield (~ 10 %). The elution buffer (10 mM Tris-Cl, pH 9.0, 0.1 mM EDTA) offers strong protection against enzymatic degradation and is optimal for long term storage of DNA. However, other low-salt buffers or nuclease-free water can be used if preferred. For more details on optimizing elution, please refer to “Considerations for Elution & Storage” in the product manual.

source.title: PART 1: SAMPLE LYSIS

source.description:
Weigh the appropriate tissue amount and place in a 1.5 ml microfuge tube (see table below or 
Choosing Input Amounts
 for recommended input amounts).
AB
1STARTING MATERIALRECOMMENDED INPUT AMOUNT
2Rodent tailup to 25 mg
3Brainup to 12 mg
4Fibrous tissue (muscle, heart)up to 25 mg
5Ear clips, skinup to 10 mg
6Liver, lungup to 15 mg
7Spleen, kidnecup to 10 mg

AB
1STARTING MATERIALRECOMMENDED INPUT AMOUNT
2Rodent tailup to 25 mg
3Brainup to 12 mg
4Fibrous tissue (muscle, heart)up to 25 mg
5Ear clips, skinup to 10 mg
6Liver, lungup to 15 mg
7Spleen, kidnecup to 10 mg

description:
Genomic DNA Purification Consists of Two Stages:
  • Part 1: Sample Lysis
  • Part 2: Genomic DNA Binding and Elution
